prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for 'scamming' my roomate?
 

Hey, I moved into a new apartment the 15'th december 2018 with 2 acquaintances, the apartment got 3 bedrooms, 2 of them are smaller and the bigger one is about 40% bigger than the other 2.

So before we moved in, I asked my roomates (let's call them X and Y) who was taking the big room, X says that he doesn't care, Y says that he really wants it. Now, I really wanted that room as well, so I asked "Okay, do you want to randomize(I don't know the right word) who gets it or should the highest bidder get it?(The one who offers to pay the most extra rent for it). Y says that it's not fair because he doesn't have as high of an income as I do, arguing that then I would get it and that wouldn't be fair. So I gave in and we went to [random.org](https://random.org/) and I won the roll (To clarify, the big room is now rightfully mine for the taking).

After about 3 days, Y says "I NEED the big room to fit my bed in it blablalba, what is it going to take for me to get the room instead of you?" so, once again I finally gave in and said "I really want the big room as well, but if you pay 30$ of my rent every month, you can have the room instead of me, that's what it's going to take for me to give up the big room." Y agreed.

Now fast forward to yesterday, X is really mad and he's claiming that I'm scamming him for money, he argues "It's not fair that you and me got the same m\^2 room, but you're paying 30$ less rent. He's really upset about this and he's basically saying i'm an asshole which is scamming him for money, saying that I should have taken this up with him as well.

AITA?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The main issue is about the author's decision to charge their roommate Y $30 more to swap rooms. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong.

First, the initial setup: three roommates, one big room and two smaller ones. When moving in, they decided to randomly assign the big room, and the author won. Then, after a few days, Y wanted the room and offered to pay $30 extra. The author agreed to the swap, but now X is upset because he's paying less.

So, X's argument is that the author is scamming him by creating a situation where he pays more for the same room. The author is taking money from Y, which effectively makes X pay less. But wait, how does that work? If the total rent is split among three people, and the author is getting $30 from Y, does that mean the total rent remains the same? Let me think.

If the original rent is split equally, each pays 1/3. When Y pays the author $30 to get the big room, the author is effectively getting more money, which might mean the total rent isn't split evenly anymore. So X is paying the same as before, but the author is getting an extra $30, so X's share might be less? Wait, maybe not. If the total rent is fixed, and the author is giving up the big room in exchange for $30 from Y, that $30 could be going towards the rent. So perhaps the author is not just keeping the $30 but using it to adjust the rent split.

But the problem is that X wasn't part of this agreement. The author made a private deal with Y without consulting X. So X feels excluded and that the arrangement is unfair because he's paying less. The author might be in the wrong if the agreement between them and Y affects X's share without his consent.

In roommate agreements, usually, any changes to the distribution of rent should be agreed upon by all parties. The author made a deal with Y that impacts X's financial burden. Even though the author didn't take anything from X, the fact that Y is paying more to the author might mean that the original equal split is disrupted. If the total rent remains the same, but the author is receiving $30 from Y, then the author's share of the rent could effectively be reduced, making X pay more than he should. Wait, maybe not. If the author is getting $30 from Y, perhaps that's an adjustment to the rent. So if the original rent is $X per month, each roommate pays $X/3. But if Y is paying the author $30 to take the big room, maybe that's an additional amount, so the total rent remains the same, but Y is now paying more in total. So Y's total payment would be (X/3) + $30, while the author's payment is (X/3) - $30, and X remains at (X/3). But that would make the author's share effectively lower, and X's the same. However, in reality, the author might not be reducing their own rent but keeping the $30. If the author doesn't adjust their own payment, then the author is profiting $30 from Y, which isn't part of the original rent agreement. This could be seen as unfair to X, who isn't part of the deal.

Another angle: when they initially assigned the room via random.org, it was fair. Then Y wanted to swap, so they agreed on a price. The problem arises because the author didn't involve X in the agreement. Roommate agreements shouldn't be done in a way that one person's deal affects another's without their consent. So, even if the author and Y made an agreement, if it changes the financial dynamics for X, that's a problem. The author should have discussed with X how the room assignments and rent splits would work, especially since all three roommates are involved in the total rent.

So, the author is in the wrong because they made a deal with Y that affects X without including X in the discussion. The fairness isn't just about the initial assignment but also about how the financial aspects are handled among all roommates. Therefore, the answer would be A (Yes, the author is in the wrong).
